page.title: 14SHOOTING SYNDICATES
page.content: A diagonal line between squares 4 and 9 roughly divides the area betwed two shooting syndicates. Hundreds(no-one is willing to disclose exactly how many) of pheasants are reared in Raisdale to the South and are turned off at six weeks old onto the whole area. The shares in the shoots are called guns and each man or gun pays his share for a keeper and the costs of birds and beaters. Beaters are employed locally on shooting days. Their job is to send the birds into the air. The owner of the southerly area employs a full time keeper and farms the land. The owner of the land to the North owns a gun shop in Stokesley - the nearest market town. He has had two ponds dug on his land and has encouraged mallard ducks and other water fowl to inhabit them, in the hope of further sport.
